awd_titl_txt: Conference: Solvable Lattice Models, Number Theory and Combinatorics
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the participation of US-based researchers in the Conference on Solvable Lattice Models, Number Theory and Combinatorics that will take place June 24-26, 2024 at the Hamilton Mathematics Institute at Trinity College Dublin.  Solvable lattice models first arose in the description of phase change in physics and have become useful tools in mathematics as well. In the past few years a group of researchers have found that they may be used to effectively model quantities arising in number theory and algebraic combinatorics. At the same time, other scholars have used different methods coming from representation theory to investigate these quantities.  This conference will be a venue to feature these developments and to bring together researchers working on related questions using different methods and students interested in learning more about them.

This conference focuses on new and emerging connections between solvable lattice models and special functions on p-adic groups and covering groups, uses of quantum groups, Hecke algebras and other methods to study representations of p-adic groups and their covers, and advances in algebraic combinatorics and algebraic geometry.  Spherical and Iwahori Whittaker functions are examples of such special functions and play an important role in many areas. The website for this conference is https://sites.google.com/bc.edu/solomon-friedberg/dublin2024.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported the participation of 16 US-based researchers (most grad students or postdocs) in the Conference on Solvable Lattice Models, Number Theory and Combinatorics, held at Trinity College in Dublin, Ireland, June 24-26, 2024. The conference featured speakers from North America, Europe, the Middle East and Asia, and served to explain and disseminate exciting new connections emerging between solvable lattice models in relation to special functions on p-adic groups and covering groups, uses of quantum groups, Hecke algebras and other methods to study representations of p-adic groups and their covers, and advances in algebraic combinatorics. Additional support for this event was provided by Boston College and Trinity College Dublin's Hamilton Math Institute.

On June 24, 2024 there were lectures by Christian Korff( Univ. of Glasgow), Jasper Stokman (Univ. van Amsterdam), Anna Puskás (Univ. of Glasgow), Henrik Gustafsson (Umeå Univ.), and Andrew Hardt (Univ. of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign), and also a poster session. On June 25, 2024 there were lectures by Manish Patnaik (Univ. of Alberta), Nadya Gurevich (Ben-Gurion Univ.), Claire Frechette (Boston College), Valentin Buciumas (POSTECH) and Daniel Bump (Stanford Univ.). On Wednesday June 26, 2024 there were lectures by Ed Karasiewicz (Nat. Univ. ofSingapore), Fan Gao (Zhejiang Univ.) and Vidya Venkateswaran (CCR-Princeton) and also time during which participants met in small groups for research collaboration. All lectures were one hour long.

The conference website, which remains accessible, is here:  https://sites.google.com/bc.edu/solomon-friedberg/dublin2024 . This website includes links to several videos that are intended for those wishing an introduction to the mathematics treated at the conference.  Research coming out of this conference is being published in refereed mathematics journals.
